title: Manchester United won badly enough to give Jose Mourinho chance to rev the fans up for Liverpool's visit
text:
Sport Opinion Manchester United won badly enough to give Jose Mourinho chance to rev the fans up for Liverpool's visit A tepid performance was still sufficient to beat plucky, undermanned Hull in the first leg of the EFL Cup semi but team and crowd need to be much better on Sunday Share Mourinho grumbled about the lack of noise from the Man United supporters (Photo: PA Wire) Share Get Manchester United FC   Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
This is unmistakably Jose Mourinho’s Manchester United now, after a ninth straight win put them on the brink of the EFL Cup final. 
But it was goals from two men signed by the much-maligned David Moyes – who lasted just 10 months at Old Trafford – that saw the Reds plant one foot on the Wembley turf. 
Juan Mata and Marouane Fellaini scored the goals that will give Mourinho a shot at a fourth League Cup triumph – and a first trophy as United manager - next month, to stand alongside Sir Alex Ferguson and Brian Clough. 
Despite the 2-0 win over visitors Hull, however, Mourinho was in no mood to celebrate, berating his players for celebrating Mata’s goal with half-an-hour left, and the crowd for a perceived lack of enthusiasm. Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Jose Mourinho speaks after win over Hull Share this video Watch Next 
Mourinho had a point, with Old Trafford strangely subdued for a semi-final, the football on the pitch failing to ignite the famous stadium as the home side dominated without ever excelling. 
World-record £89million signing Paul Pogba ran the game from midfield, showcasing his majestic vision, range and execution of passing, but there was little else to excite the crowd. 
Mata’s 56th-minute goal gave United the lead their dominance deserved, but it wasn’t until substitute Fellaini’s 87th-minute header that the home fans could finally relax. 
Ravaged by injuries, illness and Africa Cup of Nations call-ups, Hull could only name six substitutes, such was the depleted nature of newly-appointed boss Marco Silva’s squad. United were firmly on top throughout but didn't score for almost an hour... (Photo: Getty) ...until Mata got on the end of a Henrikh Mkhitaryan nod-down (Photo: Action Images via Reuters) 
Against that backdrop, the Tigers deserved huge credit for limiting United to one goal until Fellaini effectively killed the tie with his looping header, which was followed by a touchline embrace with Mourinho. 
If Mourinho was concerned about a lack of atmosphere, his cleverly-timed post-match message surely ensured there will be no such worries for Sunday’s visit of arch-rivals Liverpool, where the air will be thick with acrimony and the decibel level as high as it can go. 
Here, however, it was a different story; a tepid performance from United, who were always in command but never needed to hit top gear against spirited but ultimately inferior opponents. 
They made a blistering start and could have been ahead after just 90 seconds, Matteo Darmian finding Mata, whose first-time shot was palmed away superbly by Eldin Jakupovic. 
Hull could ill-afford to lose any more players, but were forced into a change in the 16th minute when Marcus Henriksen suffered a shoulder injury. Already struggling for players, Hull lost Markus Henriksen to injury early on (Photo: Reuters) Read More Mourinho admits to mixed emotions over impending Morgan Schneiderlin exit 
The midfielder came off worse in what looked a 50-50 challenge with Pogba and departed with his right shoulder in a sling, another casualty and selection headache for Silva. 
United maintained their impressive start but squandered another chance in the 18th minute when Henrikh Mkhitaryan shot wide after fine build-up play involving Wayne Rooney, Darmian and Mata. 
Mourinho’s side laid siege to the Hull goal, with Pogba forcing a fine save from Jakupovic and Marcus Rashford sending a dipping shot just over. 
The visitors made a rare foray towards the United goal just after the half-hour mark, with Adama Diomande heading against a post — although he was ruled offside. Fellaini's late second all but ensures a trip to the Wembley final for United (Photo: Action Images via Reuters) Read More Man United 2-0 Hull — Player ratings from the semi-final first leg at Old Trafford? 
Sub Abel Hernandez had a chance to put the Yorkshiremen ahead just before the break, but his angled shot lacked penetration and was gathered by David De Gea. 
Pogba produced a majestic cross-field ball five minutes after the restart, picking out Rooney with unerring accurancy, the United skipper applying an equally impressive first touch. 
But Rooney, seeking a record-breaking 250th United goal to move clear of Sir Bobby Charlton, steered his angled shot inches wide of the far post. 
The opener duly came six minutes later, Pogba again at the heart of the move, spraying the ball out wide to Antonio Valencia. Rooney will have to wait a little longer to break United's goals record (Photo: Action Images via Reuters) Read More "It's not over yet" - Mata preaches caution after Cup semi-final win over Hull 
He crossed for Mkhitaryan, who climbed above David Meyler to nod the ball down, and Mata reacted first to plant the ball in the net. 
Rooney was replaced by Anthony Martial with half-an-hour to go, so will have to wait to plunder that record-breaking goal. 
There was still time for Pogba to strike the frame of the goal with a fine free-kick, before Fellaini netted to put United in pole position ahead of the return leg on Thursday January 26. Like us on Facebook
